Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Development of a novel bioprotectant with fungicidal and biostimulant properties
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project will be in developing a crop protective agent that reduces negative environmental impacts and improves overall crop yield. Many common food crops, including tomatoes and peppers, are highly susceptible to fungal contamination; these organisms are rapidly developing resistance to the chemical pesticides widely used today. The objective of this project is to develop and test a new biofungicide consisting of beneficial fungi to protect plants from variety of diseases and plagues. This solution does not cause harm to the environment and offers a way to manage pesticide-resistant pathogens, which cost approximately $10 billion in the farming market. The proposed project will optimize the biofungicide for the many types of soils, crops and pathogens common across the country. A series of laboratory tests will be conducted to determine the optimal composition of the solution.

The proposed project involves designing an effective bioprotectant and biostimulant, consisting of two different Trichoderma strains, to provide enhanced protective effects against harmful fungi and bacteria, with the added benefit of boosting plant health and improving overall crop yield. This project will develop new formulations of the blended strain biofungicide to provide maximum flexibility in their application, stability for storage and delivery, as well as testing and optimizing their efficacy in new and unproven combinations of plants, soils and growing conditions. The merits of the bioprotectant anti-fungal have already been demonstrated in preliminary experiments, but only for limited combinations of crops and soils. Relevant environments will be tested in this project. Additionally, previous tests have been conducted with dry formulations of Trichoderma, and thus the proposed research will focus on the two key objectives of (i) proving efficacy in new contexts and (ii) developing stable liquid formulations. To this end, a wide matrix of formulations will be tested with a variety of soils, crops and pathogens.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project "Development of a novel bioprotectant with fungicidal and biostimulant properties" seeks to protect the environment and the health of people when they consume their fruits and vegetables introducing to farmers bio-nutrients for their farms. The biofungicide that iQBiotech is working on is a proprietary blend of Trichoderma fungal strains, natural symbionts of many food crops, which provides enhanced protective effects against harmful fungi and bacteria, with the added benefit of boosting plant health and improving overall crop yield. This potential product is derived from well characterized strains of Trichoderma, known to stimulate healthy root systems and to activate plant immune systems while outcompeting pathogens for access to available nutrients. As a biostimulant, the new product will also lead to decreased overuse of chemical fertilizers.

The merits of the bioprotectant anti-fungal have previously been demonstrated in successful proof-of-concept experiments conducted outside the United States, although with other crop and soil combinations. The main technical challenge achieved is to demonstrate that these similar advantages could be obtained on a domestic scale. The study focused on demonstrating efficacy in new contexts and investigate the develop of stable formulations.

The main results that investigate and demonstrate the efficacy of the 4 Trichoderma strains were the following:  The first showed favorable results of 4 Trichoderma to suppress or inhibit the mycelial growth of Colletotrichum (isolated from mango, gloeosporioides species complex), Phytophthora (isolated from avocado root tissue), and Pestalotiopsis (isolated from diseased strawberries). Those pathogens were tested under relevant crops and conditions in Florida. Here, a combination between strains or a combination with chemical fungicides in Integrated Pest Management could potentially have even better results.

The second showed strains of Trichoderma spp. can produce and secrete volatile and non-volatile metabolites capable of inhibiting other organisms' growth without physical contact between them. The third showed that one of the Trichoderma can produce antibiotics with strong inhibitory activity on the growth of phytopathogenic fungi. The level of inhibition (efficacy) is around 86%, 87% and 100% for the three pathogens tested.

Additionally, favorable results were obtained between two strains with commercial chemical pesticides, having a compatibility effect of up to 2-4 hours for the vast majority of samples.

Protecting crops from fungal, bacterial contamination and rot is critical to sustaining a safe food supply in the United States and across the world. Many major food crops, such as tomatoes and peppers, are highly susceptible to fungal contamination, and these fungal and bacterial strains are quickly gaining resistance to the chemical pesticides now in use. Developing a more widely protective agent that minimizes negative environmental impacts while increasing crop yield will be a beneficial technological disruption in the agriculture business.

 


Last Modified: 05/19/2021
Modified by: Jose Antonio De Cote
